title: British former headmaster of Chinese branch of Dulwich College jailed in Singapore for smoking drugs
text:
The British former headmaster of a £36,000-per-year Chinese branch of Dulwich College has been jailed for 10 months in Singapore for smoking methamphetamine.

Damien Michael Charnock, 60, formerly head of Dulwich College Shanghai, a Chinese offshoot of the exclusive south London public school, admitted possession and consumption of the drug, officials said Tuesday.

He was arrested in March at an apartment in Singapore where 11 packets of the crystalline substance, known as ice, and a glass pipe for smoking it were discovered.

Charnock pleaded guilty to three drug charges, and the attorney-general's chambers confirmed he was jailed on Friday.

Damien Michael Charnock, 60, formerly head of Dulwich College Shanghai, the Chinese branch of the exclusive south London public school, admitted possession and consumption of the drug, officials said Tuesday

Charnock, used to be the head of Dulwich College Shanghai (pictured: the games fields in China), a branch of the exclusive London private school

His offences represented 'a precipitous fall from grace', defence lawyer Remy Choo told the court, according to CNA.

In his mitigation, Choo added: 'His life's work as a talented and immensely devoted educator lies in tatters ...

'He has been a priest, a principal, a loving and devoted son, and he is unspeakably ashamed of the disrepute he has brought upon himself.'

He had been smoking crystal meth since 2017 and was employed as a curriculum developer at the time of the offences, the court documents said, without mentioning who his employer was.

Charnock, who was born in Preston, grew up in Carlisle and Kuala Lumpur, his father working for the British armed forces, according to the BBC.

He studied philosophy and theology at the University of London before he was ordained and then turned to teaching.

In an interview in 2015, Charnock said he was appointed to work at the Shanghai institution in 2014 after years as a headmaster at a school in London.

He was headmaster at Wilson's grammar school for 15 years and had also been a deputy head before that at Latmyer in London.

Singapore has extremely tough drug laws including the death penalty for traffickers

Singapore, which has tough anti-narcotics laws, punishes consumption of methamphetamine with a jail term of up to 10 years, and a fine of up to 20,000 Singapore dollars (£11,300).

Dulwich College, founded in the 17th century, has followed the trend of numerous British public schools in exporting its brand to Asia.

Four Dulwich Colleges have been established in China, one in South Korea and another in Singapore.
description: Damien Michael Charnock, 60, formerly head of Dulwich College Shanghai, the Chinese branch of the exclusive south London public school, was jailed in Singapore on Friday.
